background: Stay at home orders are also known as safer-at-home orders, movement control orders in Southeast Asia, or lockdown restrictions in the UK. These orders are put in place by government authorities to limit movement during epidemics or pandemics, often referred to as (self-) quarantine, (self-) isolation, or lockdown. An example of this was seen in the San Francisco Bay Area in March 2020 during the COVID-19 outbreak, where a shelter-in-place order was issued. Studies have shown that stay-at-home orders effectively encourage people to remain at home, and numerous such orders were implemented globally in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

background: Stay-at-home orders, also known as stay in place orders or shelter-in-place orders, are directives issued by governmental authorities during emergencies or pandemics like the COVID-19 pandemic. background:
== Terminology ==
During the COVID-19 pandemic, various terms were used interchangeably to refer to stay-at-home orders around the world. Italy, Spain, France, and other countries implemented strict quarantine measures that were coined as lockdowns by the media. However, Governor Andrew Cuomo of New York preferred the term stay-at-home order over shelter-in-place to avoid causing panic associated with emergency situations like active shooter scenarios or nuclear wars. Similarly, in Chicago, Mayor Lori Lightfoot emphasized the distinction between Illinois' stay-at-home order and concepts like lockdowns or martial law to prevent confusion among the public.

== Legal Matters ==
Amidst the global response to the COVID-19 crisis, many countries, including the United Kingdom, enforced stay-at-home orders, curfews, and quarantines as part of their measures to contain the virus spread. These restrictions were implemented to limit social interactions and movement, aiming to reduce the transmission of the novel coronavirus.
